narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project 'req_8f03ec1fc5' aims to examine social communication and neurodevelopmental profiles in youth with autism compared to typically developing peers. The types of scientific data expected to be generated include demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral and cognitive assessments, neuroimaging and/or physiological measures, derived variables, and documentation such as protocols, data dictionary, and README files. The estimated amount of data is substantial, given the multi-modal nature of the datasets from youth participants, with neurobiological data representing the largest portion of storage.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data generated from this project will be preserved and shared through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), including demographic and clinical datasets, behavioral and cognitive assessments, neuroimaging, physiological measures, derived variables, and associated documentation. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate research on autism and social communication, enabling other researchers to validate findings, explore new hypotheses, and contribute to the development of more effective interventions.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer: To facilitate the interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible: study protocols, data collection instruments, data dictionaries explaining variable names and definitions, README files detailing data processing and analysis steps, and any other information necessary for understanding and replicating the research findings.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools, software, and/or code are needed to access or manipulate shared scientific data. Specifically, neuroimaging data will require software such as FSL (FMRIB Software Library) or AFNI for analysis, while statistical analyses of behavioral and cognitive data may utilize R or Python with libraries like pandas and NumPy. These tools and software can be accessed through their respective websites or repositories.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. For demographic and clinical datasets, standards from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Data Dictionary and the PhenX Toolkit will be used. Neuroimaging data will adhere to the BIDS (Brain Imaging Data Structure) standard for organization and description. Behavioral and cognitive assessments will follow standards set by their respective measurement tools. If applicable, data will also comply with the FAIR principles (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable).

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository that supports the sharing and reuse of data related to mental health research.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the assignment of a persistent unique identifier, such as a DOI (Digital Object Identifier) for datasets, and through standard indexing tools available in the NDA repository. This ensures that the data can be easily located and accessed by other researchers.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data will remain available indefinitely through the NDA repository, subject to any limitations imposed by consent agreements or privacy protections.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Factors that may affect subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of the scientific data include informed consent restrictions and the need for privacy and confidentiality protections. Given that broad data sharing consent/assent has been obtained as appropriate, data will be shared in a manner that maximizes accessibility while respecting these limitations.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to certain parts of the scientific data may be controlled due to privacy concerns or restrictions imposed by informed consent documents. In such cases, access will be managed through the NDA's controlled access procedures, requiring approval for access to sensitive data.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all shared data will undergo de-identification processes as necessary. The use of Certificates of Confidentiality, where applicable, will further safeguard against disclosure of identifiable information. Data sharing agreements will also include terms that require recipients to adhere to strict confidentiality and privacy standards.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI), in collaboration with the institution's research data management office. Regular oversight meetings will occur quarterly, or as needed, to review data sharing progress, address any issues related to data access or confidentiality, and ensure that all shared data adhere to the standards and timelines outlined in this plan. The PI and designated data managers will be responsible for ensuring that all project personnel understand their roles and responsibilities in implementing the Plan.
